title: Six Flags Entertainment Corp (SIX) Q3 2018 Earnings Conference Call Transcript
callText:
Image source: The Motley Fool.

Six Flags Entertainment Corp  (NYSE:SIX)Q3 2018 Earnings Conference CallOct. 24, 2018, 9:00 a.m. ET
Contents:

Prepared Remarks
Questions and Answers
Call Participants

Prepared Remarks:
Operator
Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to the Six Flags Third Quarter 2018 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Maria, and I will be your conference operator for today's call. During the presentation, all lines will be in a listen-only mode. After the speakers' remarks, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions) Thank you.
I will now turn the call over to Steve Purtell, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.
Stephen Purtell -- Senior Vice President, Investor Relations
Good morning, and welcome to our third quarter call. With me are Jim Reid-Anderson, Chairman, President and CEO of Six Flags; and Marshall Barber, our Chief Financial Officer.
We will begin the call with prepared comments, and then open the call to your questions. Our comments will include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Federal Securities Laws. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those described in such statements, and the company undertakes no obligation to update or revise these statements.
In addition, on the call we will discuss non-GAAP financial measures. Investors can find both a detailed discussion of business risks and reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to GAAP financial measures in the company's annual reports, quarterly reports, or other forms filed or furnished with the SEC.
At this time, I will turn the call over to Jim.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Thank you, Steve. Good morning, and welcome to our call. I'm pleased to report that year-to-date revenue and modified and adjusted EBITDA are at record levels as our company drives toward its ninth consecutive record year. Our LTM modified EBITDA now stands at $585 million, representing growth of $39 million over prior year. I'm very proud of our team for overcoming challenges year-after-year, consistently innovating and finding new avenues for growth.
Although we did not experience the dramatic hurricane events of last year's third quarter, weather was a net drag on attendance growth during Q3. Sustained rain on the East Coast coupled with heat and rain in Texas, did not allow us to gain the expected weather advantage over 2017. In addition, severe flooding at Six Flags over Texas and Hurricane Harbor, Arlington forced us to temporarily close those parks in late September.
Without any doubt, this was the worst third quarter weather we have experienced since I came to the company nine seasons ago. Weather had a significant adverse impact. Hundreds of thousands of visits worse (ph) than both the nine-year average and versus 2017, hard as that may seem to believe.
As a result, late achievement of our P-600 goal in 2018 has become more challenging. Yet our entire team is focused on delivering the best performance possible and we still consider late achievement probable, based on the multiple opportunities we have for the balance of the year. We are confident about our ability to deliver a very strong fourth quarter performance for several reasons.
First, we grew our Active Pass Base as of September 30th, by 9% due to the launch of our 2019 season passes of memberships. Even as we increased prices in the mid-single digits and for the first time sold our higher tiered memberships. Our average selling price of new memberships was more than 25% higher than our traditional memberships. And our record high active membership base is more than 25% higher than prior year.
In August, we rolled out the foremost membership rewards program in the industry bar none. Members can earn points toward a wide array of exclusive rewards and experiences that make their memberships even more valuable. This will encourage more guests to sign up for memberships and existing members to visit more often, spend more when in the park and stay in the program longer.
Second, we have continued to grow our all season dining program, including membership dining. We have increased our penetration to record levels and now there are more than 1 million active dining passes for the first time in our company's history. As a result of the successful sales of all seasonal product, new memberships and season passes, deferred revenue is nearly $200 million, up $14 million or 8% at the end of the quarter to our highest third quarter balance ever. This is despite the downward pressure on deferred revenue that comes from members, who have been with us more than a year.
Third, Magic Mountain will be open every day in the fourth quarter after moving to a 365-day operation at the beginning of this year. The transition has been extremely flat and Magic Mountain will have more -- 35 more operating days in Q4 versus last year.
Four, our Mexico parks have fully recovered from the earthquake last year and are poised for nice growth in the quarter. Hurricane Harbor worse (ph) effect will have 21 additional operating days in Q4, as the park was closed for the majority of Q4 last year due to the earthquake damage it had sustained.
Fifth, we introduced fright fest at our newly acquired Darien Lake Park and we'll introduce holiday in the park at both Six Flags Great America and Frontier City.
Finally, we continue to grow through our international agreements. We have added seven new license parks since last year and our quarterly run rate for revenue has increased more than 50%. We have successfully grown revenue and profit in the fourth quarter every year for the last eight years by investing in our seasonal events and increasing our Active Pass Base. In fact, the majority of our growth has come in the first and fourth quarters and we expect this trend to continue this year, as an increasing number of guests are drawn to our world-class Fright Fest and Holiday in the Park event.
Our membership program is growing with unit sales through September up more than 40% over last year. Over time, the success will further spread revenue more evenly across the quarters, increasing the size and stability of our recurring revenue model. We continue to develop a sustainable business model that ensure a stable and consistent cash flow and revenue delivery and protection against both bad weather and an economic downturn.
I will return to discuss our longer term business prospect, but first I will ask Marshall to review our third quarter and year-to-date financial results. Marshall?
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Thank you, Jim. In the third quarter, year-over-year total revenue increased $39 million or 7% as a result of a 5% increase in attendance and $11 million or 42% growth in sponsorship, international licensing and accommodations revenue. Guest spending per capita was up slightly to the prior year quarter with admissions per capita spending up $0.23 or 1% and in part spending down $0.15 or 1%.
Higher ticket pricing and higher selling prices for our new premium membership tiers were offset by lower per capita spending in the newly acquired parks, which included a higher mix of water park attended. On a year-to-date basis, revenue was up $92 million or 8%, driven primarily by a 6% increase in attendance and a 23% increase in sponsorship, international licensing and accommodations revenue.
The attendance gain was driven by the newly acquired parks. Full year operation of the two water parks we acquired last year and 365-day operations at Magic Mountain. Guest spending per capita was up 1% or $0.61 the prior year, due to higher priced tickets and memberships, partially offset by lower spending at the newly acquired parks and a higher mix of membership in season pass attendance.
Year-over-year cash operating costs were up 14% in the quarter, primarily driven by the following areas: Cash operating expenses including the associated leasing expense related to our five new parks, which had significantly lower operating margins than our existing parks, an increase in minimum wages particularly our California parks and competitive wages in other market and investments to support continued growth in our high margin international licensing business.
Year-to-date cash operating costs were up approximately 10% of 2017, primarily for the same reason. Excluding the incremental spending associated with our growth initiatives, our operating cost increases were in line with inflation for both the quarter and year-to-date. Over the past eight years, we have demonstrated a significant focus on managing costs with respect to both operating expenses and capital spending and this year is no exception.
We are willing to spend in support of profitable growth, we are very disciplined about not adding cost in other areas of the business. We've driven our modified EBITDA margins from 24% to more than 40% and our modified EBITDA less CapEx margin to more than 31%, significantly higher than any of our competitors. We continue to be by far the most efficient company in the industry with respect to cost management.
In the first nine months, we generated $240 million of adjusted free cash flow and paid $198 million in dividends. Net debt as of September 30th was $2.0 billion and our net leverage ratio was 3.7 times adjusted EBITDA with no borrowings under our revolver. Given the high recurring nature of our revenue, strong cash flow and significant growth opportunities, we have plenty of room to grow our dividend by high-single digits for this foreseeable future.
Our business continues to evolve for the long-term growth and the changes we have made are positively transforming our business model. As our membership dining and international licensing programs continue to grow, a larger portion of our revenue base is recurring and it's been spread more evenly throughout the calendar year shifting attendance and revenue pattern.
Eight years ago, two-thirds of our attendance came in the traditional summer months, while now it represent less than half. The trends will accelerate in 2018 as we will have more than 20% additional operating days in the fourth quarter compared to 2017. This has lowered our weather risk significantly by making us less dependent on a few key summer months.
This year, we significantly increased the proportion of memberships in our Active Pass Base, including premium tiers that have raised the average selling price of memberships. Our members pay more and have significantly less turnover, there is a near-term accounting impact as we convert more people from one-day ticket and season passes to membership. A portion of new membership revenue will be recognized in the first half of next year, while revenue from one-day tickets and season passes would have been fully recognized in 2018.
Also, as members enter their 13th month after the compulsory period has ended, there is no other contributed to deferred revenue as their payments are recognized monthly. If you account for the increase in these post compulsory members, we estimate the growth in deferred revenue over the prior year would've approximately doubled.
Turning to international licensing, our strategy remains an important opportunity for the long term. There's always a potential for short-term challenges when working in emerging markets and our partner in Dubai, DXBE has had performance challenges with the Phase 1 complex that opened a few years ago.
As a result, we are currently conducting a strategic review of their assets in a particular Phase 2, which includes our park. DXBE is evaluating options with regard to the way forward and while there can be no assurances as to the ultimate outcome of the evaluation, DXBE is current on all their financial obligations to us.
In summary, we are on course to achieve another record year in 2018. We are very confident in our setup for continued above industry growth in 2019 or beyond.
Now, I'll turn the call back over to Jim. Jim?
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Thank you, Marshall. I want you to know that we are well positioned for long-term growth and that the outlook for 2019 is bright. We have increased prices on all ticket types. Our Active Pass Base is at an all-time high, which for the first time includes a growing mix of premium membership tiers and our all-season dining pass continues to increase its penetration to record levels.
With the addition of Magic Waters in Rockford, Illinois next year, we will have 26 parks in our system, increasing our addressable market and making us more geographically diverse. Tourists visitation will continue to build with greater awareness at Magic Mountain as the park moves into its second year of 365-day operation, and we have the ability to expand operations in some of our other warm weather parks.
Next year, we will open Fiesta Texas in San Antonio year-round on weekends and we'll expand our calendar in Mexico, adding additional operating days in Q1 and Q4. Innovation is in our DNA and year-after-year, we raised the bar to offer unparalleled world-class thrills with something new in every park. Next year, we will showcase a sweeping collection of world record breaking roller coasters and family attractions, along with massive park upgrades and rebrand for the 2019 season.
At Magic Mountain, we're introducing West Coast Racers, the world's first racing launch coaster. This will be the park's 20th roller coaster more than any other theme park, extending the park's position as the thrill capital of the world. At Great America, Max Force, a triple record breaking launch coaster with the fastest acceleration in North America. At Discovery Kingdom, Batman: The Ride, an innovative 4D free spin wing coaster. At Fiesta Texas, The Joker Wild Card, the tallest and fastest spinning pendulum right in the world. And at Six Flags of the Texas, we're introducing Lone Star Revolution, the world's largest loop coaster.
We are also rebranding our water park at our Great Escape Resort in New York to Hurricane Harbor in conjunction with a major expansion of the park. Looking longer term, we are working hard toward our aspirational goal of $750 million of modified EBITDA by 2020, which has become a very high bar (ph) on time achievement. But, our entire team is energized and motivated to try to deliver on the challenge.
The opportunities in front of Six Flags are substantial and still in the early to middle stages of development. Five key growth initiatives will drive revenue and margin for the foreseeable future. The first area is increasing ticket yields. We've taken pricing up 3% to 5% on every ticket type and added higher priced membership tiers, yet our value for money ratings have continued to grow to all-time highs. Our overall guest satisfaction scores have increased very nicely over 2017 and are also at all time highs. The second area is increasing sales of memberships and season passes.
Our newly enhanced membership program has the potential to be transformative and is still in its first year. Member spend more annually on their subscriptions than the cost of a traditional season pass and they also have much higher retention rates than season pass holders. Growth of our Active Pass Base should accelerate next year and beyond as we bring on new membership tiers layers.
The third area of growth is in-park sales, especially culinary revenue. Our all season dining pass and dining membership programs provide a tremendous value for our guests and a high-margin recurring revenue stream for us. In addition our planned introduction of mobile dining next year will help further drive customer satisfaction and supercharge culinary revenue. The fourth growth area is our strategy to acquire parks nearby our existing theme parks.
We are aggressively adding parks to expand our addressable market and build upon our significant and growing Active Pass Base. Over the past 24 months, we have added seven smaller parks to our portfolio at very low cost and we recently announced another lease agreement for a 43-acre water park in Rockford, Illinois, an important feeder market for Great America. We expect the lease to commence shortly before the park opens for the season in the spring of 2019.
The five of parks we acquired in June will also contribute over 100 operating days in the first half of next year. Finally, the fifth area of growth is international licensing. We have 13 parks under development and have a great pipeline of potential new deals that create a high margin diversified source of recurring revenue with no capital investment. Six Flags provides family entertainment that is affordable in any economic environment. We consistently deliver guest excellence, innovative products and attractions, and of course record revenue adjusted EBITDA and modified EBITDA less CapEx performance.
Since 2010, we have returned over $3.4 billion to shareholders in the form of dividends and share repurchases and we will continue to return all excess cash flow in the future. We have grown our dividend every year for the last eight years and our dividend yield of more than 5% is more than double the S&P 500, making us an ultimate growth and yield stock.
Maria. At this time, could you please open the call for any questions.
Questions and Answers:
Operator
Thank you. (Operator Instructions). Our first question comes from the line of Ian Zaffino of Oppenheimer.
Mark Breidenbach -- Oppenheimer -- Analyst
Hey, good morning guys. This is Mark on for Ian. Thanks for taking.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Good Morning, Mark. How are you.
Mark Breidenbach -- Oppenheimer -- Analyst
I'm doing well. How are you. So, I guess on to begin -- if you guys can provide I guess I'll breakdown the components of the headwinds call out in the quarter that would be very helpful. So I guess on more in the sense of how much of that was the result of weather EPR and others? Thanks.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
So we won't actually break out the attendance that way, but what we can say is that year-to-date our attendance is up 6% or 1.4 million people, driven by the acquisition of the five new parks, 51 additional days at Magic Mountain. Growth from Hurricane Harbor Mexico and Concord, and the increase in our Active Pass Base. Jim mentioned that the weather was horrendous in the quarter and year-to-date and hit several hundred thousand in attendance, that we lost due to weather, several hundred thousand higher than the nine-year average. And versus last year.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
So I'm going to address a question that's come up -- came up on the last call and it's come up in some of the reports that have already come out and so I'll just address this straight up so that everybody is aware of our position. We do continue to get these questions about what described as organic versus inorganic growth and we are not going to be breaking that out.
We've said before, we don't do this for competitive reasons and will continue not to break it out. We have never ever broken out park detail. We have outlined five key imperatives, which will drive our future success. And we've been consistent about that approach. We view all of the growth that we have achieved as organic, the five initiatives that have been there a long time and the organic growth flows from those five growth pillars which reinforce a higher value strategy, make barriers to competitive entry even stronger, spread our revenue out over the year, help drive recurring revenue and continue to reinforce what I've described about a year ago, as the Amazon proof nature of our company.
In addition what we're doing is not like a traditional major acquisition. We have put minimal capital into any of the new park initiative, are simply one of those five growth pillars. Nonetheless, we know and want you to feel comfortable with our record performance.
So I want to confirm, clearly as I said eight years ago when I joined the company, our focus is 100% on driving profitability and cash flow and therefore shareholder value that has been the same literally over the last eight years, if you look on a year-to-date or last 12 month basis, not only are we at record performance, the highest the company has ever registered, roughly 3 times the value of modified EBITDA that the company had back in 2010. If you look at that we have grown revenue and EBITDA, whether or not the five new parks are included and this will be our ninth record year.
Mark Breidenbach -- Oppenheimer -- Analyst
Okay, great. Thank you very much, Jim. And I guess just a quick follow up. Is there any, I guess details on the margin profile of EPR assets that you guys could share. Just want to, I guess like, think of how to think about on a run rate basis and long-term going forward. And on top your six, I guess, legacy margins? Thanks.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
So, I'll provide a little bit of color on that. The new parks are first of all, they're lower margin and lower per caps. We think we can get those margins up over time, as we put in our season pass template and our dining templates, our membership templates as well. On top of that, there's a lease expense that comes with them and the lease expense does push down margins, but I will tell you that, and we knew that going into this the investment that we made and the ROI on this investment of $23 million is incredible and it is -- the payback is very quick and so while we know it does put downward pressure on margins. We think we can get the margins up and we are extremely satisfied with that.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
I'd answer that Marshall just by saying, we've talked about the facts that I think people may be assumed that a lot of or all of that attendance falls in Q3 and it doesn't. I talked about the fact that we've got some attendance is coming in Q4, some is coming in Q1 and Q2 next year. That's more than 100 days that I talked about coming in, in the first half of next year that we didn't have this year. So it's important to understand that this is spread over the year and to build on Marshall's point, it's very, very positive. We feel really good about the new parks and I think they're off to a fantastic start.
Mark Breidenbach -- Oppenheimer -- Analyst
Okay, great. Thank you guys, very much.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Thanks you.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Thanks Mark.
Operator
Our next question comes from the line of Steve Wieczynski of Stifel.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Hi Steve, good morning.
Steve Wieczynski -- Stifel -- Analyst
Good morning guys. So Jim, we would like to hear your current thoughts on the core -- on your core customer base and the health of your core customer. And I guess what we're getting on here is when we -- when you had days when weather wasn't an issue, is your core customer is still strong as what you would have expected?
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Yes, I would say, Steve. Very clearly that on days that are not impacted by weather, our core customer strong. I'd add to that the comments that both Marshall and I made about some of the trends we're seeing with our Active Pass Base being up 9%, amazing growth that I described there with regard to membership and memberships at the premium level selling at a far-higher level than we had previously anticipated. So, we feel that consumers overall are in a very good shape, at least in decent shape. They're looking for great values and we feel that we do offer a really good value and a family offering that is unparalleled.
We're building, as I described earlier, competitive barriers to entry that really make it difficult for anyone's payable to penetrate our markets. And so, when you look at that, the overall view, I would give is, I feel pretty good about where we are.
Steve Wieczynski -- Stifel -- Analyst
Okay. Got you. And then, second question is kind of a bigger picture question around the consumer. So, Jim as you talk to your core customers, have you got any sense that with people essentially having less free time than they do in the past. Do you sense other family entertainment offerings that require a smaller time commitment, could be starting to eat away at demand for full day theme park visits? And then kind of on that same page, is that question, Jim. Given how strong the economy currently is, do you believe some of your customers are essentially buying up into bigger or more extravagant vacation alternatives and potentially moving away from going to your parks?
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
So, I think, Steve, to the point that the first and most important thing is to understand that our active people signing up, want to be with us, whether they are season pass holders or members, are up 9% on the record that we had last year. So, that would point you to a very clear indication that people love coming to our parks and are consistently signing up for that. That's point number one.
To take each of the items that you argued there or at least put forward, one was, are there folks switching to shorter visits or are they switching to longer visits going to a Disney or Universal? And we just have not seen that. We really haven't. I think that's really what we saw was just a horrendous weather quarter that has impacted us, yet we still delivered record revenue and profitability and that's our goal.
We want to deliver cash flow, profit grow shareholder value. So, we've not seen anything that would indicate there are shorter offerings that are more attractive to guests or that people are switching to bigger vacations. Just not happening.
Steve Wieczynski -- Stifel -- Analyst
Okay, got you. Then one more quick one, if I could. Jim, you talked about the 750 for 2020 is now, I think you referred to it more as a high bar at this point. Can you maybe help us think about what has changed since you put that target out there? I know you don't like talking about weather, but is it more weather-related issues or is it the international component? I know you've had some issues in certain markets over there might that not be kicking in quick enough to bridge that gap?
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
I don't think so to the point of what has changed. I think the reality is that we've had a couple of rough weather years and there's no doubt that we would have preferred to be at a higher point today, so that the 750 target would have been a little easier to achieve. It's the big growth and it requires a lot of hard work. But, and if you look at our history, we have delivered on projects and we're working very aggressively, not only to deliver 750, but also 600.
And I feel very good about the five key initiatives that I talked about earlier. We have been taking ticket pricing up successfully. Nothing has changed there to make us concerned. Membership and season pass penetration and that's going extremely well, nothing has changed there to make me concern, in-park revenue and just the success we've had with our all season dining pass is fantastic.
And I would argue, and I said this to you before that we maybe in the third innings on dining. The North American expansion strategy with these new parks, there are lots of opportunities for us still to succeed there and international licensing. We've added seven new parks in the last year. So, I don't look at any of these and say, OK well fast (ph) not working. We really haven't succeeded or anything like that. I feel like we have been slammed by weather. We have the right imperative. I wouldn't change a single thing in terms of what we're doing and we're going to aggressively go after it. But it's realistic to say that the growth to date in EBITDA hasn't been at the level that we would have liked it to have had if weather had cooperated.
Steve Wieczynski -- Stifel -- Analyst
Okay, great. Thanks, guys, thanks for the color.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Thanks, Steve
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Thanks, Steve.
Operator
Our next question comes from the line of James Hardiman of Wedbush Securities.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Hi, James.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Hi, James.
James Hardiman -- Wedbush Securities -- Analyst
Hi guys. How are you doing?
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Great.
James Hardiman -- Wedbush Securities -- Analyst
Thanks for taking my call here. Maybe a little clarification. Jim, a couple of times you mentioned all the operating days you're going to be getting from your parks. Maybe it would be helpful, if you don't want to give us sort of actual numbers, just help us understand the phasing of premier parks relative to your existing business? I think the third quarter attendance has typically for you guys been somewhere between 40% and 50% of the year public (ph) parks, similar to that is it outside in one direction or another? Maybe just help us out with that?
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
The phasing, why don't you take this Marshall?
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Yes. So, those parks, there's three water parks and then the two other parks. One of which is in Buffalo, they have been more traditional summertime attendance. So, with the Oklahoma, for example, it does have some Q1, Q2 attendance and operating days. But, in general, it's Memorial Day to Labor Day, they're probably heavier penetrated in those -- that time period.
Now, we will be changing that over time. We're adding Holiday in The Park the this year at Frontier City. We'll be doing some spring events at all of the parks and ultimately we will do what we've done at the rest of our parks, extend this the operating season. We've already started selling memberships and so, ultimately that's one of the ways we're going to grow the margins there and also grow the profitability there as like expanding the calendar.
James Hardiman -- Wedbush Securities -- Analyst
Got it. And then, I think the term you used was probable but you get to the target for this year. I guess first just remind us what the target is, I want to say it was 605 once you added premier parks? And then, I know you don't like to talk about post quarter results, but presumably, if you think it's probable, what you've seen so far in the quarter? So, I'm assuming probably have two quarters in the bag at this point maybe clarify that? If not, I'm assuming that what you've seen thus far suggest that you're very much on pace to get to that number?
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
So, James, 605.3 is our number, $605.3 million. We are not going to talk about the current quarter. I think you know, we have never done so and won't do so today. And your point that half of it done is not correct. We still have two-thirds of the quarter left in terms roughly in terms of attendance.
James Hardiman -- Wedbush Securities -- Analyst
Okay, that's very helpful.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Still a long away to go.
James Hardiman -- Wedbush Securities -- Analyst
Yeah, OK. And then, I guess lastly for me, the commentary on Dubai. I believe that park was initially slated to open in the fourth quarter of next year. Should we be pushing that back given that I'm assuming you didn't have a whole lot of wiggle (ph) room to get that into 2019? And then, I guess more broadly, I think it was three Chinese parks that were expected to open in the fourth quarter of next year as well? Maybe give us an update on those guys construction, how's that coming along? Anything you can give us would be great.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
High level and maybe Marshall, you can then talk through timing. I think it's fair -- when you heard my commentary -- the commentary early that Marshall talked about Dubai, but at a high level, given their strategic review, it probably makes on time opening in 2019 unlikely. And I think on our next call, we probably be able to talk more clearly about what's that opening would be or when it would be. But Marshall, with the exception of Dubai, why don't you go through all the other parks, which are on time.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Okay. So, you mentioned the Chinese parks, we -- they start to come online in Zhejiang, theme park, water park and kids park are in early 2020. The Chongqing parks are during 2020 as a theme park, a water park, kids park and an adventure park. Those are mid 2020. And then, Nanjing, those will start to open up in 2021, the water park, kids world first, the adventure park in 2021 as well in Nanjing. And then the Nanjing theme park will actually open up in 2022 mid-year. Then that leaves Saudi, which is scheduled to open up in 2025.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
And I want to reinforce that, that's an incredible lineup of new parks to come and a lot of revenues that will come. But, concurrently, we have a small team that is working very aggressively on other partners and other (inaudible). And over time, as I've said before they like they are basically like M&A deals will announce them as soon as we have news, but don't forget that we are working on those in the background.
James Hardiman -- Wedbush Securities -- Analyst
Okay. Just to clarify, I thought the first round of Chinese parks were originally slated for late next year, did I just get that wrong or did those get pushed back?
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
They have -- technically, it's the first of 2020, I think ultimately earlier we were saying late 2019, which was in the fourth quarter. So, it really, the shift is a month or two. It's not much.
James Hardiman -- Wedbush Securities -- Analyst
Got it. Okay, thanks guys.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Thanks, James.
Operator
Our next question comes from the line of Brett Andress of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
Brett Andress -- KeyBanc Capital Markets. -- Analyst
Hey, Good morning.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Good Morning.
Brett Andress -- KeyBanc Capital Markets. -- Analyst
I just wanted to dig a little bit more into your weather comments from earlier, but you said it had an impact of hundreds of thousands of visits, I guess, can you elaborate a little bit more on that specifically how many, hundreds of thousands of visits, I mean it is a pretty wide range to think about it?
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Sure, it is a wide range. So in very and we we have mechanisms for tracking this very carefully. In very simple terms, If you go back over the nine -- the nine-year, or nine season period that I have described. It's 700,000, if you simply look year-on-year, it's 500,000.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Yeah, I think maybe some more color and I'm not sure if you mentioned already, but we had 1/3 more bad weather days in Q3 than we did last year. That's pretty significant. It was a worst Q3 weather since 2011. The weather is going to improve. It's not going to be this way forever. I think what sets us apart though, is that we have five growth engines and four of them deliver and we have record year-to-date performance both in revenue and in EBITDA, so we got the growth engines that delivered internationals. The North American expansion strategy, policies in dining, pricing, yielding and the membership programs.
So, we are doing what we need to do to drive the business and the weather will improve. It's not going to be worse than average forever because the average -- we're going to get back to the mean at least. So we are very confident in what we're doing and we know that weather will clear and we'll get great growth again.

Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer

Brett Andress -- KeyBanc Capital Markets. -- Analyst
Got it. And that's specifically just international.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
That is international.

Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer

James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
In other words, with the growth that Marshall talked about, Tim, with that growth, we've had to add, literally, handful of people and that add some cost, it's part of the growth in the cost base and that's the reason.
Tim Conder -- Wells Fargo Securities -- Analyst
(Multiple Speakers) 80% of the margin --
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer

Tim Conder -- Wells Fargo Securities -- Analyst
Okay. Okay. Okay.

Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Yeah, So it's really the costs associated with the new parks, the lease expense associated with the new parks. And then mandated minimum wage increases and competitive wage rate increases in several markets. But, but if you take out the spending that we did to grow revenue, our costs are up with inflation and that's including the minimum wage costs that we've been working to offset. Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer

Tim Conder -- Wells Fargo Securities -- Analyst
Okay. Okay. I guess on the membership versus the season passes, kind of where is that in the total Active Pass Base and maybe that percentage year-over-year?
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
So, we not breaking out the percentage of our total Active Pass Base that is membership in that way, but we can tell you that membership, as I described earlier, is up tremendously very, very strong growth and season pass is holding its own fairly nicely. So we feel pretty good about the overall position. We did, and maybe we describe, we did have a little bit of a hick-up in the quarter. Marshall just talk a little bit about the issue that we have with our flash sale and some people are aware of this and some aren't.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Yes, so in terms of flash, we have a flash sale in September for our season passes and memberships. It's our annual pre-sales, which allows us to lock pass holders and members in advance, encourage visitation both in the fourth quarter and the following year. We did experienced technical difficulties with our third-party online ticket stores, for that, we had to take our parks offline as we approach the Labor Day deadline. As a result, we extended the deadline to allow guests to complete their purchase. We did see the expected volume spike a week later when the new deadline happen, but it is likely that some sales were lost. So, I think that would sort of --
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer

We are feeling very, very good about where we are.
Tim Conder -- Wells Fargo Securities -- Analyst
I agree, credit card data especially in theme parks to me, has never made that much sense given with especially growing memberships you can charge that credit card each month, so it doesn't give you that kind of an indication versus in-park spend or anything over all. Thank you gentlemen for the color.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer

Our next question comes from the line of Barton Crockett of B. Riley FBR.
Barton Crockett -- B. Riley FBR -- Analyst

Barton Crockett -- B. Riley FBR -- Analyst
Hi, there. good morning, thanks for getting back on the line after that interruption there and getting me into the Q&A. I guess I was wondering a little bit more about Dubai. I'm wondering if you could explain what it means for a strategic review to be taking place, if that means that potentially the park doesn't even launched the second phase and if there is any risk or there is no risk to fees you've already collected having to be reversed, which I think it's something that happened in Vietnam, as there's a risk here if things totally fell apart of that happening?
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
So first of all, there is no risk to fee, fees having to be reversed and I think you heard Marshall talk earlier about the fact that they are up-to-date on their payments. So, there is no such risk. With regard to strategic review, we cannot speak for our partner. They have a Phase 1 that launched with several parks, they had a Phase 2 plan to launch with other businesses, including our park. They are going through a strategic review because that Phase 1 has not, basically not going well.
So they're trying to work through what they do next. We don't have an answer. I wish I could give you an answer to say this is what will happen, but the risk for us is minimal, and I would tell you that this was our smallest park in terms of our expectations with regard to revenue and EBITDA, in terms of the outlook. So, while we would never want the park, not to go ahead. If it happens, it's something we would manage through very successfully.
Barton Crockett -- B. Riley FBR -- Analyst
Okay. And so when you make that comment that it's your smallest. In the past, you guys have given a range of pre-opening fees $5 million to $10 million in EBITDA contribution from those fees. And I think $10 million to $20 million post opening, by saying this is the smallest, would it be fair to put that at lower end of the range (multiple speakers).
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
The lower end of the range, as we've given you in the past, Barton.
Barton Crockett -- B. Riley FBR -- Analyst
Okay, all right. And then switching gears a little bit to that. The membership, are you guys kind of starting to get a meaningful up membership fees in the first quarter of next year. It strikes me that you did the big kind of push starting this year, you've talked about 25% increase for a 25% more average revenue per member. And I think the monthly accounting be kicks in after someone's been there 13 months, so we kind of start to notice this in the P&L in the first quarter of next year, which is seasonally small, so that revenue lift could be very noticeable.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
So.Barton, you're right on the money. Your accounting skills are very good. And in fact that's right about the 13th month once that kicks in. You move to the monthly basis and I think if you think about Q1 this year, you saw some of that benefit as we were growing members, but now we've accelerated that. So you will see a spreading of revenue, not only in terms of Q1, but also Q2 and Q4, the lighter quarters are impacted in a positive
way. And then the heavier quarter which is Q3, does get an impact the other way, which we, Marshall had talked about, there's a softening of revenue in Q3, because some of that membership money does move into other quarters.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Right. And actually, I don't know if we mentioned but, nearly half of our membership base now is passed their 12-month commitment, which is a pretty significant step. So, we're going to get growth. The real growth, as you correctly pointed out, will start to come in Q1, although we didn't really launched that program until the end of February, so it will be, we'll have a group of, I guess, the tranche of sales that are going to go into the 13th month in March, but then really in April, May, June this big growth that we've had this year, will start to move into their, into their 13th month. So, I suspect we'll see a bigger impact in in the second quarter.
Now, we have seen growth year-over-year, just as we've been selling memberships nevertheless, several years and they've been staying with us. So, -- but will accelerate in Q2.
Barton Crockett -- B. Riley FBR -- Analyst

Hi, Michael.

Actually what was driving the SG&A is two things, really it's the non-cash comp where last year we had a credit related to project 600, as we went from partial achievement to late achievement and then beyond that, the marketing for the new parks ends up in SG&A. And so that's really what the other, I guess the other driver of SG&A is marketing the new parks. Most of the remainder of that falls into the operating expenses, but the marketing does go into the SG&A.
Michael Swartz -- SunTrust -- Analyst
Okay, that's helpful. And then I just again a point of clarification, are you saying that the baseline rate of cost inflation is still within the 3% to 4% range, is what I think you cut out before?
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
That's correct.
Michael Swartz -- SunTrust -- Analyst
Okay, that's helpful and then just as we see more and more, I guess, of your Active Pass Base maybe shift toward membership, give us a sense of what the retention or maybe the annual value of those membership customers looks like relative to season pass holders?
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
So with it before, how powerful this is. And I think the very simple way to think about it, and it's overly simple, is that if you have a member with a dining pass, you're looking at five times the value of a single-day visitor and roughly two to three times the value of a season pass holder.That's very, very high level, that's how powerful it is.
And if you extend that through and you think we've taken an assumption there on a member that might just give up their membership at a fairly early date. If you assume that they stay with us and we're seeing a load of them stay with us, that relationship goes up in a fairly dramatically from 5X to much higher.
Michael Swartz -- SunTrust -- Analyst
Okay, thanks.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer

Our next question comes from the line of Tyler Batory of Janney Capital Markets.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Hi Tyler.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Hi, Tyler.
Tyler Batory -- Janney Capital Marke -- Analyst
Hey, good morning. Thanks for taking my questions. Just wanted to follow up a little bit on the membership side of things, when you look at the members that you've added year-to-date, you really seeing a lot of growth there. I mean how many of those folks are brand new guests that have never visited the Six Flags versus single-day ticket holders last year that are now converting versus maybe to pass holders that are converting or maybe even members that are buying a higher tier pass?
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
We have that data Tyler but we're not going to break it down. What I will tell you is that our focus has been on converting the guests we have, very aggressively. So, by far the highest proportion our existing guests that we're converting across. And we're not just doing it online. We're also doing it very aggressively in the parks and we're getting better and better at doing it. So it really is a very high proportion of our existing guests. And what we are working hard to do is not just convert them to becoming a member, we're converting them to becoming a diamond or a diamond elite member of the much higher price points and then selling them culinary programs at the same time and other membership type deals.
So that's the goal. Early on, it's hard work but as you get better and better as we have been, we are seeing that success come through. And I think, in essence, what happens is that the revenue lags a little bit just because some of that shift into future years. As you go through that growth spike.
Tyler Batory -- Janney Capital Marke -- Analyst
Okay. That makes sense. That's helpful. And then just a follow-up, here when you mentioned adding some incremental operating days to San Antonio and I think Mexico as well. If you talk a little bit more about that what drove that decision, maybe how many extra days are going to be coming in 2019? And could what you're adding be a significant of an impact is Magic Mountain this year?
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Well, let me Marshall answer that question. But let me give you a high -- high-level view. Your point on Magic Mountain there is really critical. We have had such a great a reaction to Magic Mountain being open 365 days a year that it led us as, I described on the last call, to really look at all of our parks and see where we could do this.
And we had two parks -- a lot of parks and we would like to do it. But two parks slugging it out to say, they would like to add, it's become much broader in terms of opening and so both of those have said they would like to do it. And we have looked in detail at the consumer and our guests when they visit, what the best period would be and hence the decision. So, you want to talk about Mexico and Fiesta in the detail?
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Yeah, I think the detail is for Fiesta, we're going weekend operations, which will pick up 14 days in the first, mostly in the first quarter. Mexico is expanding their calendar. I think Mexico is apart, ultimately they can be 365 days, it's a huge market. But we are doing much like we did in Magic Mountain, we're testing days. We are making sure we can be profitable on every day that we're open.
So, we are expanding the calendar, the first and the fourth quarter there as well. And it's an iterative step, I think ultimately assuming those days go well, which we fully expect they will. We'll be looking at 365 days beyond that. And then Jim also mentioned the new parks have over 100 days in the first half that we didn't own them last year.
Tyler Batory -- Janney Capital Marke -- Analyst
Okay, great. That's very helpful. That's all for me. Thank you.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Thanks.
Operator
Ladies and gentlemen, our final question comes from the line of Ryan Sundby of William Blair.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Hi Ryan.
Ryan Sundby -- William Blair -- Analyst
Hey guys. Thanks for taking my question. Just wanted to follow up on the tuck-in strategy and the potential network that you can create from that. Is there maybe any color you can give us around Texas? And how maybe Active Pass growth has looked at Six Flags Over Texas and Fiesta after the addition of the water park here in Houston?
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
So again, I think this is one Ryan that we want to see a full year to be able to give a little more color on that. But I can tell you that the reaction not just from guests, but also from our teams have been incredibly positive with regard to the new parks that have been added. And we've structured it so that those new parks slip in under Fiesta and under Six Flags Over Texas.
So, reaction very positive, guests love it. They love the fact that they can visit multiple parks and be able to go to a different water park if they want to. So the initial view has been extremely positive and we're seeing it. If you think about the comments that I made about membership and the success with the growth in membership and our Active Pass Base. That I think is the number one representation of why this has been received so positively of millions and millions of season passes, we're growing by another 9%. And I think not only that we've taken pricing up. We've taken pricing up even more on memberships and we've got more Active Pass Base holders.
Ryan Sundby -- William Blair -- Analyst
Got it. And then I guess just a follow-up on weather here. What's -- is there a cumulative impact that happens from kind of bad weather, maybe one or two years in a row. Because it seems like intuitively should be able to recapture, the loss kind of attendance in profits this year. But then, I'm trying to judge that against your comments on, you set a 50 target and how that might have been hurt by weather? So just any thoughts on, is there a cumulative impact kind of attendance next year --?
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
It's a really good question, Ryan. You do, we have consistently said that in a sort of normal year, you will get weather here and there. And people will find ways of just visiting at different times and come back and you'll recapture that weather. I think that, that would be the case normally. And we do believe that. I think the issue here is that those numbers are just so significant. It's very difficult to be able to recapture that.
So we'll aim to do that and we'll work hard to do that. I think in terms of this year, you said we'd work hard to do that, but I think it will be very difficult to be able to recapture that for the shortfall.
Marshall Barber -- Chief Financial Officer
Yeah. And if you just look at the percentage growth for us just sit up here and confidently say we are going to grow 12% a year through 2020. We do think when weather normalizes that there will be, will come roaring back, but it's the numbers are just big enough now to where we say it's, we're going to work hard to get there, but it is, it's a high bar.
Ryan Sundby -- William Blair -- Analyst
Yeah, that's all. Thank you.
James Reid-Anderson -- Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer
Okay. Maria, I think that maybe the end of our questions. So I'm going to make some closing remarks. And while talking about weather and the last comment Ryan made, while there were clearly dark clouds in the sky during the third quarter, I do want you all to know that the future is very bright.
Our team is really deeply committed to building lasting memories for our guests and to drive substantial value increases for our shareholders. Remember that almost all of our full-time employees are shareholders and so there is tremendous alignment of interest across this company. This is my favorite time of the year in our parks, mostly because of how much our guests love fright Fest and I hope that you will visit one of our parks very soon, so that you can experience amazing Fright Fest and Holiday in the Park events.
And do not forget, we're currently sitting at a 5.4% yield. This is an amazing value company. This is the time to buy 6 lakh shares. Thank you so much for joining us today and take care. Maria, that concludes our call.
